title: Accession of Montenegro to the European Union
text:
Accession of Montenegro to the European Union (EU) is on the current agenda for <a href="Future%20enlargement%20of%20the%20European%20Union">future enlargement of the EU</a>.
The <a href="Serbia%20and%20Montenegro">State Union of Serbia and Montenegro</a> started the process of Accession to the <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a> in November 2005, when negotiations over a <a href="Stabilisation%20and%20Association%20Agreement">Stabilisation and Association Agreement</a> began. In May 2006, <a href="Montenegro">Montenegro</a> voted for independence in a <a href="Montenegrin%20independence%20referendum%2C%202006">referendum</a> and the <a href="State%20Union%20of%20Serbia%20and%20Montenegro">State Union of Serbia and Montenegro</a> was dissolved. <a href="Serbia">Serbia</a> continued with the existing negotiations, and separate negotiations were launched with <a href="Montenegro">Montenegro</a> in September 2006. The Agreement was initialled on 15 March 2007 and officially signed on 15 October 2007. In 2010, the Commission issued a favourable opinion on Montenegro's application, identifying seven key priorities that would need to be addressed for negotiations to begin, and the Council granted it candidate status. In December 2011, the Council launched the accession process with a view to opening negotiations in June 2012. The accession negotiations with <a href="Montenegro">Montenegro</a> subsequently began on 29 June 2012. With all the negotiating chapters opened, the country enjoys a widespread support among EU members' officials, and accession of the country to the EU is considered possible by 2025. In its 2016 assessment of the accession progress, European Commission has identified Montenegro as having the highest level of preparation for membership among the negotiating states. Until 2020, Montenegro had received €507 million of developmental aid from the <a href="Instrument%20for%20Pre-Accession%20Assistance">Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance</a>, a funding mechanism for EU candidate countries.
Application.
Montenegro officially applied to join the EU on 15 December 2008. On 23 April 2009, the Council invited <a href="the%20European%20Commission">the European Commission</a> to submit its opinion on the application. The Commission presented Montenegro with a questionnaire to assess its application on 22 July 2009. On 9 December 2009, Montenegro delivered its answers to the EC questionnaire.
Stabilisation and Association Agreement.
Negotiations on a <a href="Stabilisation%20and%20Association%20Agreement">Stabilisation and Association Agreement</a> (SAA) between Montenegro and the European Union started in September 2006. The agreement was officially signed on 15 October 2007, and on 1 May 2010 it came into force, after all the 27 member-states of EU had ratified the SAA.
Recommendation.
The European Commission on 9 November 2010 recommended Montenegro as candidate country. This candidate status was officially granted on 17 December 2010.
Progress.
Montenegro is experiencing ecological, judicial and crime-related problems that may hinder its bid. Montenegro signed an agreement with the Bulgarian government in December 2007 in which Bulgaria will assist Montenegro with its Euro-Atlantic and EU integration for the following three years. To work on these matters the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Foreign%20Affairs%20and%20European%20Integration%20of%20Montenegro">Ministry of Foreign Affairs and European Integration of Montenegro</a> has a special agency dedicated to accession to the EU, the Office for assistance to the Chief Negotiator. The goal of the office is to support the task of the Chief Negotiator for Montenegro's Accession to EU, Zorka Kordić. On 27 July 2010, the Parliament passed a <a href="LGBT%20rights%20in%20Montenegro%23Discrimination%20protections">non-discrimination law</a> that includes <a href="sexual%20orientation">sexual orientation</a> and <a href="gender%20identity">gender identity</a> as prohibited grounds of discrimination. This was one of the requirements the country had to meet for EU membership.
Domestic opinion.
Montenegro's population is overwhelmingly pro-EU, with 76.2% being in favour according to polling and only 9.8% against, in October 2009.
Visa liberalisation process.
On 1 January 2008, the visa facilitation and readmission agreements between Montenegro and the EU entered into force. Montenegro was added to the list of visa exempt nationals on 19 December 2009, allowing their citizens to enter the <a href="Schengen%20Area">Schengen Area</a>, Bulgaria, Cyprus and Romania without a visa when traveling with biometric passports. Visa liberalisation process does not include travels to <a href="Republic%20of%20Ireland">Ireland</a> as this country operate its own respective visa regime outside of the Schengen Agreement.
Unilateral euro adoption.
<a href="Montenegro">Montenegro</a> has no currency of its own. As a <a href="constituent%20republic">constituent republic</a> of the <a href="Socialist%20Federal%20Republic%20of%20Yugoslavia">Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia</a> following <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, and later of the <a href="Federal%20Republic%20of%20Yugoslavia">Federal Republic of Yugoslavia</a>, Montenegro used the <a href="Yugoslav%20dinar">Yugoslav dinar</a> as its official currency. In November 1999, the government of Montenegro unilaterally designated the <a href="Deutsche%20Mark">Deutsche Mark</a> as its co-official currency with the dinar, and on 1 January 2001 the dinar officially ceased to be a legal tender in Montenegro. When the <a href="euro">euro</a> was introduced and the Deutsche Mark yielded in 2002, Montenegro followed suit and began using the euro as well, with no objection from the <a href="European%20Central%20Bank">European Central Bank</a> (ECB). The <a href="European%20Commission">European Commission</a> and the ECB have since voiced their discontent over Montenegro's unilateral use of the euro on several occasions. A statement attached to their <a href="Stabilisation%20and%20Association%20Agreement">Stabilisation and Association Agreement</a> with the EU read: "unilateral introduction of the euro was not compatible with the Treaty." The EU insists on the strict adherence to <a href="convergence%20criteria">convergence criteria</a> (such as spending at least 2 years in the <a href="ERMII">ERMII</a> system) which are not negotiable before euro adoption, but have not intervened to stop the unilateral adoption of the euro by Montenegro in 2002. The issue is expected to be resolved through the negotiations process. The ECB has stated that the implications of unilateral euro adoption "would be spelled out at the latest in the event of possible negotiations on EU accession." Diplomats have suggested that it's unlikely Montenegro will be forced to withdraw the euro from circulation in their country. Radoje Žugić, Montenegro's Minister of Finance, has stated that "it would be extremely economically irrational to return to our own currency and then later to again go back to the euro." Instead, he hopes that Montenegro will be permitted to keep the euro and has promised "the government of Montenegro, will adopt some certain elements, which should fulfil the conditions for further use of the euro; such as adopting fiscal rules."
Negotiation progress.
There are currently thirty chapters opened, three chapters that have been provisionally closed, and two chapters in which there is nothing to adopt.
